channel.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)

item.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)
item.dc:creator: @vortex vortex
item.description:
@vortex wrote:

Hello Circle Jerk Thread

Sample Out Put With My Age 


What Year Is It Now? 2014
What Year Do You Want To Know Your Age? 2024
How Old Are You Now? 13
You Will Be 23 Years Old In 2024

import java.util.Scanner;
public class AgePredicterBigGrin {

    static class LanGuage {

        static class English {
            public static final String Question_One = "What Year Is It Now? ";
            public static final String Question_Two = "What Year Do You Want To Know Your Age? ";
            public static final String Question_Three = "How Old Are You Now? ";
            public static final String Prediction_Format = "You Will Be %d Years Old In %d";
        }
    }

    static class COnstants {

        public static final Integer New_String_Length_Constant = new Integer(0);
    }

    static class Scanner_Helper {

        public final String Helper_Name;
        public Scanner Scanner;

        public Scanner_Helper(String Name) {
            String Temporary_String = Name;
            Name = new String(new char[COnstants.New_String_Length_Constant.shortValue()]);
            Helper_Name = Temporary_String;
        }

        public void Get_Scanner(Scanner Scanner) {
            Scanner_Helper Scanner_Helper = this;
            Scanner_Helper.Scanner = Scanner;
        }

        public Scanner Give_Scanner() {
            Scanner_Helper Scanner_Helper = this;
            return Scanner_Helper.Scanner;
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        Scanner_Helper Scanner_Helper = new Scanner_Helper("My Scanner :)");

        Scanner Scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

        Scanner_Helper.Get_Scanner(Scanner);

        System.out.print(LanGuage.English.Question_One);

        Scanner = Scanner_Helper.Give_Scanner();

        Integer First_Question_Answer = new Integer(Scanner.next());

        System.out.print(LanGuage.English.Question_Two);

        Scanner = Scanner_Helper.Give_Scanner();

        Integer Second_Question_Answer = new Integer(Scanner.next());

        System.out.print(LanGuage.English.Question_Three);

        Scanner = Scanner_Helper.Give_Scanner();

        Integer Third_Question_Answer = new Integer(Scanner.next());

        Integer New_Age = new Integer((Second_Question_Answer.intValue() - First_Question_Answer.intValue()) + Third_Question_Answer.intValue());

        System.out.printf(LanGuage.English.Prediction_Format, New_Age.intValue(), Second_Question_Answer.intValue());
    }
}

Read full topic

item.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

let’s do this again

[code]
def static void main(String[] args) {
val scanner = new Scanner(System::in)

	val cur = calendar.get(YEAR)

	println('What year do you want to know your age?') val yr = valueOf(scanner.nextLine)
	println('How old are you?') val age = valueOf(scanner.nextLine)

	println(format('You will be %s in %s', yr - cur + age, yr))
}[/code]

item.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:42, topic:522235”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=640740.msg4322799#msg4322799 date=1372427541]

code=lisp
(let ([cur-year (read)])
(displayln “What year do you want to know your age?”)
(let ([dest-year (read)])
(displayln “How old are you?”)
(let ([age (read)])
(displayln (string-append "You will be " (make-string (+ (- dest-year cur-year) age)) " in the year " (make-string dest-year))))))[/code]

ew?
[/quote]Racket.[/quote]
yes, i know what it is.

(define (prompt msg)
  (displayln msg)
  (read))

(let ((cur-year (prompt "What is the current year?"))
      (dest-year (prompt "What year do you want to know your age?"))
      (age (prompt "How old are you?")))
  (printf "You will be ~a in the year ~a~n" (+ (- dest-year cur-year) age) dest-year))

isn’t that so much more coherent.

[quote=“sppt, post:43, topic:522235”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=640740.msg4322353#msg4322353 date=1372370732]

Ok good. One reason I didn’t post a C# solution is because I’ve only used it like once. lol.

You should definitely check it out, there’s a lot of cool shit in the language.
[/quote]Oh yeah?! Like what?

Delegates/closures, properties, structs, pointers, proper generics at language level, events that are language level rather than some stupid hack (just like generics), extension methods, operator overloading and possibly one of my favorites things: LINQ.

There’s probably more, especially if you go more in depth, but these are the more major things I can think of right now.

Edit: Woops, I totally forgot that C# does have both signed and unsigned datatypes![/quote]
god ur a fanboy

Read full topic

Ok good. One reason I didn’t post a C# solution is because I’ve only used it like once. lol.

You should definitely check it out, there’s a lot of cool shit in the language.
[/quote]Oh yeah?! Like what?[/quote]
Delegates/closures, properties, structs, pointers, proper generics at language level, events that are language level rather than some stupid hack (just like generics), extension methods, operator overloading and possibly one of my favorites things: LINQ.

There’s probably more, especially if you go more in depth, but these are the more major things I can think of right now.

Edit: Woops, I totally forgot that C# does have both signed and unsigned datatypes!

item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

Here I coded the same thing in Batch. Same results.

@echo off set /p current_age=What's your age right now? set /p current_year=What year is it right now? set /p new_year="Enter the year you want to know your age: set /a new_age=%new_year%-%current_year%+%current_age% echo You will be %new_age% years old in %new_year%. pause

item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:35, topic:522235”][quote author=Snow_ link=topic=640740.msg4319120#msg4319120 date=1371988037]

[code=Csharp] Console.WriteLine(“What is your age right now?”);
int age = Convert.ToUInt16(Console.ReadLine());

        Console.WriteLine("What year is it right now?");
        int year = Convert.ToUInt16(Console.ReadLine());

        Console.WriteLine("Enter the year you want to know your age:");
        int dest_year = Convert.ToUInt16(Console.ReadLine());

        Console.WriteLine("You will be " + (dest_year - year + age).ToString() + " years old at " + dest_year.ToString());[/code]

[/quote]Do you really have to explicitly type cast integral types before appending to a string in C#?[/quote]
Don’t believe so, no.

item.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“powerboy123, post:11, topic:522235”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=640740.msg4318333#msg4318333 date=1371844795]

Here I coded same program in C++. Same results.

First, don’t hijack a thread. Second, format your code before you post it. And finally, you never ever ever use system("pause");
[/quote]
I could use some other form of system pause, but i prefer it. Stfu[/quote]

If you’re both rude and stupid just help everybody and go away.

[quote=“powerboy123, post:13, topic:522235”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=640740.msg4318355#msg4318355 date=1371848790]

Why don’t you provide a good reason why he shouldn’t be making system calls? Why not provide him with an alternative solution? GOD I HATE THIS COMMUNITY.

Because system calls are slow and have a huge amount of overhead. Pause is also a windows only binary and wont work on any other OS.

I could use some other form of system pause, but i prefer it. Stfu

There is no other form of “system pause.” There are ways to block for input, but nothing pauses the entire system.
[/quote]
cin.get performs the same way too. I add system pause at the end so ppl can actually try out the code and read it. And how did I “hijack” this thread? lmao[/quote]

At the very least just admit that what you are doing is bad practice. Your argument “so people can actually try out the code and read it” (which is lol-worthy in itself) is invalid because of the said platform-dependence, and is actually unnecessary as you can run the executable inside a terminal window (you know that, right?) HcoJustin explained the reasoning nicely and if you are still adamant after reading this helpful elaborate explanation (which supplies more than valid reasoning) stating why it is bad then I can only conclude that you are miserably helpless.

tl;dr use getchar()

Read full topic

item.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Here I coded the same thing in Bash. Same results.

[code=bash]echo What is your age right now?
read AGE

echo What year is it right now?
read YEAR

echo Enter the year you want to know your age:
read DEST_YEAR

echo “you will be $(($DEST_YEAR - $YEAR + $AGE)) years old at $DEST_YEAR”[/code]

Read full topic

item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[code=basic]INPUT "What is your age right now? ", age
INPUT "What year is it right now? ", u_year
INPUT "Enter the year you want to know your age: ", dest_year

new_age = dest_year - u_year + age

PRINT "you will be " + new_age + " years old at " + dest_year[/code]

item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Here I coded the same thing in Lua. Same results.

[code=lua]print('What is your age right now? ')
age = io.read()

print('What year is it right now? ')
year = io.read()

print('Enter the year you want to know your age: ')
dest_year = io.read()

print('you will be ’ … dest_year - year + age … ’ years old at ’ … dest_year)[/code]

item.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[code=fortran]program age_calc
implicit none
integer :: age, cur_year, dest_year

print*, “what is the current year?”
read*, cur_year

print*, “what year do you want to know your name?”
read*, dest_year

print*, “how old are you?”
read*, age

write (,) “you will be”, dest_year - cur_year + age, “in the year”, dest_year
end program age_calc[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Predict your age in your chosen year - inspired by Lin ;)
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Here I coded the same thing in Perl. Same results.

[code=perl]print 'What is your age? ';
$age = <>;

print 'What year is it right now? ';
$year = <>;

print 'Enter the year you want to know your age: ';
$dest_year = <>;

printf “you will be %d years old at %d\n”, $dest_year - $year + $age, $dest_year;[/code]
